title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: three-months-after-its-launch-how-strong-is-the-pulse-of-the-nations-newest-tv-channel
story: Itrsquos a period in which the pound million channel dedicated to Scotland and Scottish content has, at times, attracted record digital audiences, won a quarter share of Scottish viewers, been the third most-watched channel in Scotland after BBC One and STV, reached more people between the ages of  and  than any other channel in Scotland, gained serious traction on social media and, in the best of its content, made good on its promise to give Scottish audiences programmes they wonrsquot see anywhere  and which deal with the issues and subjects that affect, concern and interest them .But itrsquos also a period marked by a wild iance in audience ratings , by whispered rumours of discontent and in-fighting, by a perceived lack of brand identity and by a barrage of negative headlines either questioning the need to have the channel in the first place or pouring scorn on specic programmes, such as The Nine or Catriona Shearer-fronted gameshow Wonderball.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzLaunching BBC Scotland in Glasgow in February, BBC Director-General Tony Hall outlined the aims of the channel. As he saw it, they were to celebrate Scotlandrsquos strengths in arts, comedy, science and ldquothought. To reflect the countryrsquos ersity. To allow audiences ldquoto interrogate the things that matter to them and, along the way, to ldquoreinvent public service broadcasting. BBC Scotland, he stressed, would offer space for discussion and debate alongside opportunities to ldquokick back and have fun. It would be about the country speaking to itself but also to the world. It would be local, national and global.In other words it would be a lot of things to a lot of people. Or it would try to be. So, three months after its glitzy birth and with the numbers soon to roll over to Day  of its existence, how is BBC Scotland bedding in  What do audiences think of it  And how well is it measuring up to Hallrsquos lofty claims Steve Carson, BBC Scotlandrsquos Head of Multi-Platform Commissioning, is predictably bullish about its prospects and its track record. To his mind the station is about trying to take risks, giving a  to ldquoa strong range of voices and communities and doing ldquonew things and dferent things. So far the strike rate is good, he thinks. Among the successes he points to are Getting Hitched Asian Style, a documentary series following a wedding planning company in Glasgow, the opening night screening of Nae Pasaran , and Last Breath, a drama documentary about a North Sea er stranded on the sea-bed.Identying a stand-out is ldquolike naming your favourite child, he says. ldquoBut I think Asian Weddings is something I was pleased to see hellip It was quite straightforward but it got into communities you donrsquot often see and certainly donrsquot often see in that sort of context.For an example of risk-taking that paid off he points to Sink Or Skim, which took a fond look at the World Stone Skimming Championship held annually on the isle of Easdale in the Firth of Lorn.ldquoThatrsquos not a subject many channels would have commissioned, but it was a beautully made piece and it was funny watching it go out and looking at social media because people were going lsquoI canrsquot believe theyrsquore doing something about stone skimming. Is this part of their sport portfolio rsquo. But by the end of it the same people were going lsquoThat was really goodrsquo.Sink Or Skim was a one-off but The Peoplersquos News is a weekly discussion of topical events in which ordinary Scots go in front of the camera and have their tuppence-worth on topical events. Those featured might not have the political contacts of a Laura Kuenssberg, say, but they have something just as important: context. They represent the social and political views of people in a spread of communities distant from London and far removed from the Central Belt. Itrsquos another example of the channelrsquos guiding principle that BBC Scotland should be a  for discussion and debate and again itrsquos a programme that wouldnrsquot have aired anywhere .ldquoWe could have done a dferent version of this channel which would have been a lot less risky and done a lot more of what other channels do, says Carson. ldquoA Scottish version of BBC Four, for example, would have been a less risky proposition. But we already have that, so we felt it was important to try new things, go for harder to reach audiences and deliberately take risks knowing that not all of them ndash in fact many of them ndash wonrsquot pay off. Thats what wersquore about.So which risks havenrsquot paid off ldquoThatrsquos like naming your least favourite child, he says. ldquoI think the programmes that we have originated between pm and pm have had a tough time, but again our medium term strategy was not to originate as much there. The Nine has had ratings which have gone up and down, but wersquove always said thatrsquos a competitive slot. But on a digital channel ndash and wersquore already the biggest non-terrestrial channel in Scotland with a three per cent share, which is well ahead of projections ndash audiences will go up and down across the night and the week.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzIf therersquos a lightning rod for criticism, The Nine is it. An hour in , staffed by a team of presenters and journalists that numbers  ndash at least in the publicity shots ndash and fronted by Rebecca Curran and award-winning former ITN journalist Martin Geissler, itrsquos the stationrsquos flagship news programme.A lot rides on its wellbeing and it seems a little peaky. It was reported that on one day in late April viewing figures dropped to just . They picked up the following day, to , but even on April , the first day of the inquiry into the Clutha disaster, they couldnrsquot quite hit . From a first night high of ,, thatrsquos a signicant drop.ldquoThe Ninersquos average is signicantly higher than that figure and its reach, which is really important in news, is reaching a quarter of a million a week, Carson counters. ldquoItrsquos offering something dferent. If you wanted to point at a show which is something we wouldnrsquot have otherwise done, The Nine is it ndash an hour long news and analysis programme which looks at Scotland, the UK and the world through Scottish eyes.So is it simply the right show but in the wrong time slot ldquoWersquoll see. Nine orsquoclock is a competitive slot but there is a demand there and people are turning to it. The appreciation for The Nine is very strong and wersquore finding that across the board. You might get some programmes that donrsquot have huge average audiences but the appreciation is strong.In a front page story earlier this month, London-based broadsheet the Sunday Times quoted a BBC source who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. The same source added: ldquoYou canrsquot have a channel that nobody watches. Journalists like their output to be watched and it wonrsquot be long until some of the channelrsquos main talent head for the door. Another source spoke of a ldquopoisonous atmosphere in the newsroom causing behind-the-scenes tensions which could cause key staff to walk. True or   ldquoThat is not the case, Carson says bluntly.Among the keenest watchers of how BBC Scotland has fared over these first three months is Dr Lisa Kelly, a lecturer in television at Glasgow University.ldquoIrsquove been pleasantly surprised, she says. ldquoI think I probably wasnrsquot holding out much hope at the beginning, primarily due to the budget ndash pound million for programming isnrsquot much to play with in the television landscape.To put the budget in context, the BBC is spending nearly three times that amount on the new EastEnders set. But funding aside, Kelly is excited by the apparent focus on nurturing and showcasing new talent. Shersquos also impressed by the choice of programmes and pleasantly surprised at the internationalism of its outlook. One innovation she particularly welcomes is the Next Big Thing strand, which screens short films such as as Meet Me By The Water by Scots-Asian writer-director Raisah Ahmed.ldquoI think therersquos been quite a range of programming. It seems like they are trying to be erse in terms of their representation. So obviously you have Getting Hitched Asian Style and The Nine, which is trying to tackle current debates around issues of representation. So I think it has been quite successful so far.And does it matterratings are low for some programmes ldquoI donrsquot know that it does this early on. I think itrsquos important that we have access to original Scottish programming at a local and national level.There are other challenges, she thinks, besides ratings. One is establishing the channelrsquos identity. ldquoIrsquom not quite sure what its brand is yet in terms of how itrsquos selling itself. I noticed that before the launch it was targeting young people with this notion of fresh and original ideas, but I donrsquot know whether theyrsquoll be able to sustain that.Another is proving that the bold talk ndash of nurturing young talent, giving voice to dferent groups and communities, taking risks and tackling ersity ndash will be backed by bold actions.Wherersquos the Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge, for example  And how embedded is the commitment to ersity and inclusion, to actually hearing new voices and seeing dferent stories rather than it just being rhetoric with no change Theyrsquore questions for which Steve Carson has a ready answer. Sothe Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge was out there with a project she was aching to make, is he convinced he would find her and commission it ldquoI hope so. And I think we are finding quite extraordinary talent at all levels and also stretching people who might already have done one thing but are now doing something . Like State Of It, which is Robert Florence [co-writer of sketch show Burnistoun] doing quite a scabrous satirical show. Itrsquoll be coming out in the autumn.There is data which can help, however. A measuring system known as ldquosocial listening can analyse social media responses to any subject and from that gain an insight into how that subject is viewed, expressed as the over-riding emotion associated with it.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzBBC Scotland set the algorithms running at launch and four weeks later the results came back. ldquoThe strongest emotion in social listening was surprise, says Carson. ldquoThat was really encouraging. So modern Scotland, outward looking, surprising and focussed on new talent ndash thatrsquos the core identity of the channel. SoBBC Scotland is a keyboard emoji, itrsquos a colon and a zero.Three months ago, the channel launched with a Miracle. Whether itrsquoll need another one to make it sing in the long term is harder to judge. As they probably donrsquot teach you to say in continuity announcer school, watch this space.BBC Scotland: The Good, The Bad And The NineGetting Hitched Asian StyleA behind-the-scenes documentary following Glasgow wedding planners Saffron Events as they prepare for a succession of glamorous weddings, Getting Hitched Asian Style proved so successful that it received a repeat run on BBC One and has been re-commissioned for a second series on BBC Scotland. Produced by the Scottish ision of London-based Firecracker Films itrsquos a good example of the channelrsquos stated commitment to programmes which reflect Scotlandrsquos ersity. Verdict: funny, interesting, occasionally jaw-dropping but ultimately humane.A View From The TerraceBorn out of The Terrace, a long-running podcast, AVFTT is fronted by four young presenterswho sit on sofas and talk engagingly about Scottish football. Refreshingly free of Old Firm bias itrsquos fast becoming a Friday night staple for those fans of the Beautul Game who think subjects such as the on- and off-field shenanigans of Partick Thistle legend Chic Charnley or how Eriskay has one of the best pitches in the world are as worthy of discussion as whorsquoll be the next manager of Real Madrid. Verdict: a great signing.Sanjeev Kohlirsquos Big TalkA weekly show in which the comedian is joined by a  of guests for a ldquosideways look at the big issues of the week, filmed in what looks like the foyer of the BBCrsquos Pacic Quay HQ in Glasgow in front of what looks like a smattering of audience members. ldquoI never in my le want to endure another excruciatingly mirthless hour of supposedly witty commentary on the weekrsquos news, wrote one Herald critic. ldquoIt was so awful the only way to hang on to consciousness was to watch what was happening outside the glass-fronted studio. Less trenchant criticism has concentrated on the showrsquos stfness and its uneven format. Verdict: could do better.WonderballItrsquos probably destined for cult status among Generation Z-ers as an endless source of memes, but in the here and now BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship gameshow hasnrsquot been exactly showered with love. Letrsquos not take it too far, though: Wonderball is not, as right-leaning tabloid the Daily Mail has suggested, the worst show of its type ever aired, eventhat paper might like it to be. But you canrsquot say that those who have pointed out its flaws ndash the somewhat complicated rules, say, or the unintentional snigger value of two young men being instructed to play with the blue balls ndash donrsquot have a case. It hasnrsquot been a ratings hit either, with viewership dropping as low as  for one episode. Verdict: not utterly pointless, but not likely to become the next Pointless.The NineA team of talented and accomplished presenters, a  minute running time and a news agenda that blends hard-hitting investigations with quirky or thought-provoking items hasnrsquot stopped BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship news programme taking considerable flak from some quarters. Earlier this month one newspaper talked of a ldquotalent exodus from the channel and quoted a BBC insider who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. Damage has undoubtedly been done as a result: negative news stories about behind-the-scenes tensions and potential resignations may not be true, but they contribute to a narrative of failure which becomes hard to shake over time. What is true is that ratings for The Nine have been disappointing on occasions, though in mitigation its time slot doesnrsquot help. Verdict: a rocky start for a potentially stellar offering that may flourish in a dferent time slot.

title: how-to-plan-your-perfect-tailor-made-holiday
story: Bespoke luxury holidays are a dominant force within the current climate, with more and more travellers setting their sights on worldwide locations and unique pursuits. If you are hungry for experiences, craving excitement and new cultural insights, then there are a number of experts, airlines and tourism groups with the tools to help match you with your dream bespoke holiday.Travel Counsellors ndash David BishopWhen planning a holiday, whether itrsquos a multi-stop adventure to far flung places or a week in Spain, itrsquos important the trip is tailored to you. Designing the perfect holiday is no easy task, yet with the help of a specialist travel consultant, the process can be simple and stress free.David Bishop has extensive knowledge and experience when it comes to booking holidays. After working for  years with travel experts, Trailfinders, he made the decision to become self-employed and now works under the umbrella company Travel Counsellors. With a unique network of travel professionals, independent experts like David can offer expert advice to tailor holidays to the inidual.Based in Edinburgh, David is happy to meet clients in person to discuss their trip, whether itrsquos over a coffee or via a home visit. Alternatively, he can discuss plans over the phone or through email.Taking into consideration all aspects of the trip, from the flights to transfers, accommodation to insider tips, David creates dream breaks for his clients. No matter what the destination or budget, his skills and commitment mean no details are forgotten.Some clients may seek a relaxing getaway in luxury resorts with day trips factored in others may want an action-packed break, camping under the stars or trekking amongst beautul landscapes. Whatever the plan, David can help make the dream a reality.At Trailfinders David specialised in organising premium cabins with all major airlines, along with world-class ground arrangements including the Ghan, Indian Pacic and the Transalpine. This has provided him with in depth knowledge of the luxury travel market.If clients want to visit some stunning locations, open-jaw itineraries involving cruises can be a unique way of travelling between incredible places, be it Singapore to Sydney, Darwin to Perth or perhaps Fjordland night cruises in New Zealand.He is also particularly passionate about helping clients plan holidays to Australia and New Zealand, thanks to two years spent living there and exploring the many delights of the two destinations. Much like a hotelrsquos concierge service, the personal service David provides is not limited to the flights and accommodation. He will take care of restaurant reservations, spa services, recommend night le hot spots and anything the client wishes. While away on the holiday, he will also be contactable in the rare instance where an issue occurs.Trusted and relied upon, David is a Gold TC . This means based on customer testimonials and sales, he is in the top  per centof  TCrsquos worldwide and one of very few Gold TCrsquos in Scotland.To get in touch and find out more, contact David on   , email david.bishop@travelcounsellors or visit www.travelcounsellors david.bishop----------------------------------------------------------------------------------IcelandairIcelandair operates from the UK and Ireland, serving direct flights to Iceland from five gateways: London Heathrow, London Gatwick, Manchester, Glasgow and Dublin with easy onward connections to  destinations in the USA and Canada, places such as New York, Boston, Washington.When you fly with Icelandair, you will enjoy their unique brand of Icelandic hospitality and comfort. On-board experiences include special features such as, the latest Icelandic music, comfy leather seating plus interactive in-flight entertainment systems designed to make the short flight to Iceland fly by. Passengers enjoy generous legroom, complimentary seat selection and kg hand baggage allowance as standard. At the front of the cabin, in Saga Premiumtheir exclusive luxurious seats have extra legroom, and yoursquoll have dedicated staff attending your every need, offering a pre-flight drink and later the choice of gourmet meals and fine wines.Photograph: IcelandairBefore boarding your onward flight to any of our North American destinations, why not sample the Saga Lounge. Staff will welcome you with their famous Icelandic hospitality.Alternatively, why not add an Icelandic touch to your trip when flying across the Atlantic  Stop over in Iceland for up to seven nights at no additional airfare. Visit Reykjaviacutek, the worldrsquos most northern capital, and enjoy the islandrsquos geological contrasts with some of the largest volcanoes on Earth and its magnicent glaciers. Itrsquos not called the Land of Fire and Ice for nothing.There are plenty of things you can do on an Icelandair Stopover.If yoursquore looking for some relaxing options, they recommend taking a day trip through the southwest of Iceland. Start at the Blue Lagoon on route from the airport to Reykjavik and spend your first few hours in Iceland, soaking in the milky blue water. Then head to Reykjavik for a refreshing cup of coffee downtown before plunging your feet into the Groacutetta footbath with a breath-taking view over the Faxafloi bay and neighboring mountains.Now your feet are refreshed, go for a cocktail and a lovely meal at Slippbarinn, the bar at Icelandair Hotel Reykjaviacutek Marina. Fancy a bit of adventure  After a good nights sleep, explore the legendary Golden Circle, bringing you to Icelands most famous natural attractions.Photograph: IcelandairSome of Icelandrsquos best-known jewels lie in the South, which should be at the top of your itinerary.With a well-equipped rental car, you can cover a lot of this adventurous region, with activities like ice climbing, snowmobiling, horse-back riding, swimming and visits to the famous waterfalls.Not forgetting that before you head on to the airport, make a stop at Soacuteley Natura Spa for a relaxing massage before your flight.Visit www.icelandair en-gb for more information.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Elitsa Nixon ndash Travel CounsellorsPassionate about helping customers create their perfect holiday, travel specialist Elitsa Nixon has years of experience creating bespoke trips. Based in Dumbarton Elitsa has worked under the umbrella company, Travel Counsellors, since last year as an independent travel consultant and one of the areas she specialises in is niche expedition cruises.After settling in Scotland over eight years ago, Elitsa gained a masterrsquos degree in International Tourism Management before joining a major UK tour operator specialising in itineraries to long-haul destinations such as the Far East, Middle East, Africa, Indian Ocean and Australasia.Today Elitsa specialises in cruises, particularly focusing on niche expedition cruises. An increasingly popular way to travel, expedition cruises are changing the face of cruise ship holidays. Accommodating a few hundred passengers only- as opposed to the thousands normally found on cruise ships ndash they take passengers to incredible and remote corners of the world.Expedition cruises are perfect for inquisitive adventure seekers wanting to explore places such as the Galaacutepagos Islands, Antarctica, the Arctic and Australiarsquos Kimberly Coast. These once in a letime trips take passengers to spectacular locations on smaller, custom-made cruise ships designed to navigate icy waters and gain access to places not easily accessed by visitors.As an up and coming holiday option, most travel agents arenrsquot well versed in expedition cruises. Elitsa however has a keen in interest in the specialist holidays and having worked on a cruise ship for five years, is well versed in normal cruise ship holidays too.Whatever theof trip, choice of destinations or budget, Elitsa can help create a truly bespoke cruise holiday. story: INNERPEFFRAY LIBRARYThe spectacular Library and School at Innerpeffray were founded by David Drummond rd Lord Madertie in around , the first free public lending library in Scotland. Madertie was a member of the Drummond Family, one of the most important landowning families of the area, friend and brother-in-law to James Graham, First Marquis of Montrose.The original library was "partly in the west end of the chapel of Innerpeffray and partly in that little new house lately built by me at the east end of the kirk yard." Making books available to ordinary people free of charge was unprecedented. Madertie wished the library and school to benefit the community "in time coming" and leaving them with a legacy of  Scottish Merks charged his successors with the responsibility.In  Robert Hay Drummond inherited the Innerpeffray estate and responsibility for the Library and School. He raised the funds and commissioned architect Charles Freebairn to design and build a new Library building immediately adjacent to the Chapel. This handsome Georgian edice still houses the library todayBy the nineteenth century the school buildings were dilapidated and a new School and Schoolmasters house were completed in . Pupils came from the surrounding farms and settlements and the school was still in operation until .The Borrowers Register is perhaps the Librarys most valuable book, a handwritten record all the local people to who came to choose a book, and take it home to read. Today, families from all over the world find their ancestors in the Register, often in their own handwriting, and can hold the books they borrowed.See www.innerpeffraylibrarywww.facebook innerpeffray-----------------------------------------------------CUTTING CORNERSThis professional printing service offers a wide range of photographic and fine art printing options, including fine art printing for photographers and artists,canvas printing for people looking for high quality canvas printsand - new for summer  -stunning natural wood and high gloss aluminium prints.Cutting Corners also print a wide range of full colour promotional merchandise for business, personalised gtware for anyone looking for a unique present, and their own range of artisan gtware.The firmn also deliversprofessional picture framing and printing services UK wide, so evenyou are not local, you can use theirservices and they will arrange to ship to you safely and securely.As well as a professional picture framing service with over  frame choices on display, Cutting Cornersuse the latest technology to deliver precision cut picture mounts from a choice of over  colours.The firm also stock a wide range of art supplies from brushes to paints to paper, available to buy online and from theirprint and frame studio in Dunfermline.If you have a football shirt to frame, that special photograph you are looking to print and frame, or simply looking for advice and ideas on how to frame or print your artwork, just call in to the studio or contact Cutting Corners and their friendly and knowledgeable staff will help.The picture framing and print studio is at Units AB Pitreave Crescent, Pitreave Business Park, Dunfermline, KY UT. Award winning Chef-Patron Paul Newman has travelled the world and combines international flavours with the best local and seasonal produce.Based on our Scottish Hill Farm at Errichel, we breed and raise our own Shetland Cattle, Shetland Sheep, Large Black Pigs and an assortment of hens and ducks. We keep rare breed native livestock best suited to our environment and climate. We offer tours of the farm on request and welcome you to enjoy the land, both in the gardens and out on the hill at Errichel Farm. Who will you meet when you stay Thyme Restaurant and Errichel offers Private Dining Events for your special occasion. Restaurant Trading HoursSummer pm Tuesday - SaturdayWinter pm Thursday - SaturdayFacebook:www.facebook thymetoeatscotland www.facebook Errichel Instagram:@errichel@erricheloccasionsTwitter:twitter thymetoeatscotWebsite:www.errichel--------------------------------------------------------------THE STEAMSHIPLoch Katrine has twocruise ships to take you on the beautul Loch, to admire the amazing landscape which changes from season to season. This page will tell you more about these magnicent ships and a little bit about their history.Loch Katrine has drawn tourists for hundreds of years, ever since Sir Walter Scottrsquos vivid descriptions inspired a generation of Victorian tourists to visit the loch to see the landscape for themselves.The Famous Tour No began as early as , this was a marathon day excursion by rail and steamship from the city ofGlasgow. Tourists travelled by train from Glasgow to Balloch by train, Balloch to Inversnaid by Steamer, Inversnaid to Stronachlachar by horse drawn coach, down Loch Katrine by Steamer to Trossachs Pier and coach to Callander, from where they would take the train back to Glasgow.The steamship Sir Walter Scott is the#agship and the jewel in the Loch Katrine crown. title: holyroods-presiding-officer-to-address-voter-cynicism
story: Ken Macintosh will visit every electoral region of the country to underline the importance of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos engagement with local communities.He will begin in Glasgowrsquos Maryhill  Springburn constituency on Friday, going to Skye and Banff  Buchan later in the year.The aim is to ldquoidenty and break down the barriers between voters and their politicians.Mr Macintosh, the former Labour MSP for Eastwood, said: ldquoOur th anniversary is an opportunity for people across Scotland to reflect on the dference that the Scottish Parliament has made over these past two decades to peoplesrsquo lives.ldquoMore important than that, it is an opportunity to take positive action to strengthen our relationship with local communities, helping to create an environment where people are actively engaged with the Parliament and know how to make their voice heard.ldquoIn these days of fake news and growing cynicism towards politics and politicians, it is more important than ever that we actively reach out to communities across the country and demonstrate Parliament is accessible and there for the people of Scotland.ldquoMy hope is that we can use these th anniversary events to highlight the principles on which we were founded and to demonstrate that we have never forgotten the importance of our partnership with local people across Scotland.Mr Macintoshrsquos first stop includes a discussion on Holyroodrsquos future with P and P pupils a lunch about the challenges faced by immigrants and asylum seekers meeting the head of Scotlandrsquos Regional Equality Councils to talk about barriers for ethnic communities in politics and chairing a  discussion on mental health with the local community.Bob Doris, the SNP MSP for Maryhill  Springburn, said: ldquoIt is fitting that the voice of local young people will feature so prominently, given the responsibility our Parliament has to help deliver on their hopes and aspirations, as well as to listen to their concerns.ldquoI am particularly pleased to support events discussing the challenges and opportunities to promote positive mental health in our communities, as well as to help highlight the work of ious organisations who help support and promote the values of ersity and inclusiveness across Maryhill and Springburn.ldquoMaryhill and Springburn has a proud history and bright future and we look forward to sharing this with the Presiding Officer during his visit.

title: susan-aitken-refuses-to-meet-group-over-marches-past-catholic-churches
story: Councillor Susan Aitken did notmeetleaders of the group, who have held silent protests in recent months against parades held by the Orange Order and other loyalist organisations.It is understood by The Evening Times that the Council leader was contacted in March with campaigners claiming they wrote two further letters asking for a response since they initially reached out.Despite attempts from the group,the SNP politician declined the request for a meeting, claiming she needed to remain ldquoimpartial on the matter.The council confirmed any requests for a meeting between Susan Aitken and loyal order groups would also be denied at present.A letter from Ms Aitken to Call It Out reads: ldquoGiven that work is ongoing and the imperative for the council to remain impartial ndash and be seen to remain impartial ndash throughout this process.:Plans for Protestant march past Glasgow Catholic church blasted by campaignersI donrsquot think a meeting would be helpful at this stage.ldquoI will, however, forward your views to the officers who are working on this issue and ask that they be taken into account.She also reiterated that the power to ldquochange frameworks lay within in the Scottish Parliament, and not with Glasgow City Council.Call It Out has expressed its disappointment at the council leaderrsquos decision.A spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is quite inconceivable that the leader of Glasgow City Council would refuse to meet any other minority community that wished to raise concerns about marches past their places of worship.ldquoIt is also quite inconceivable that Susan Aitken would tell the Jewish community, for instance, that she would not meet them because she had to be lsquoseen to be impartialrsquo between them and anti-Semites who were parading past synagogues.ldquoIt is not the job of political leaders to be impartial between bigots and their victims. She should withdraw that inference immediately.:Orange Walk to march past Glasgow Church where Catholic priest was attackedThe Orange Ordersaid it would be willing to meet Glasgow City Council to discuss the re-routing of loyal order parades away from churches.A spokesman for the Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland said: ldquoWersquore always willing to meet leaders of the council to look for ways to work together on the issues at hand."Ultimately, we hope they accept having religious dferences is okay, but having religious ides does more harm than good.A council spokesman reiterated a meeting ldquowould not be helpful at this particular time.He added: ldquoGiven the ongoing review of the councilrsquos code of conduct in relation to parades, our specic role in the paradesrsquo notication process and the need to resolve tensions created by recent marches and counter-demonstrations it is crucial the council remains impartial and is seen to remain impartial.ldquoIt is also important to note that the council has only limited powers in this area. Responsibility for public order rests with Police Scotland and competence for the management of processions with the Scottish Parliament

title: scottish-labour-mps-slam-leadership-saying-party-may-never-recover-from-worst-ever-result
story: Ian Murray and Martin Whitfield said Scottish voters had ldquodelivered an utterly damning verdict on the party ndash which lost its two MEPs from Scotland and fell from second to fth in the polling.:SNP European election result is endorsement of record in government - Nicola SturgeonDavid Martin had been the UKrsquos longest-serving MEP, having spent  years in Brussels, before being voted out of office ndash blaming Labourrsquos failure to take a clear stand on the crucial issue of Brexit for the result.Mr Martin tweeted: ldquoWe lost not because of lack of effort but lack of clear message.While obviously personally disappointed to lose my seat Irsquom devastated for the hundreds of good Labour people who put so much into the campaign. We lost not because of lack of effort but lack of clear message @scottishlabourmdash David Martin MEPMay , Mr Murray, the Edinburgh South MP and his East Lothian colleague Mr Whitfield, insisted the results must act as a ldquowake up call for Jeremy Corbyn and the Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard.Writing in the Edinburgh Evening News, the two MPs said: ldquoThe European election results are by far the worst results in Scottish Labourrsquos long and proud history.ldquoThere is no way to sugar-coat this ndash the people of Scotland have delivered an utterly damning verdict.Voters had told themthat ldquothey felt they had no choice other than to back explicitly pro-remain parties instead of the Labour Party, they added.And while they said it was ldquodevastating Mr Martin would no longer represent Scotland in the European Parliament they insisted he could still ldquohold his head high.The MPs insisted: ldquoThe blame for the worst result in Scottish Labourrsquos history lies squarely with our partyrsquos leadership.ldquoThis was an election campaign about the biggest issue facing our generation: Brexit. And yet we walked away from that battlefield, offering nothing but ambiguity on an issue that will determine the future of our country.:European elections  live results in ScotlandLabour came sixth in the Edinburgh City Council area, behind the SNP, the Conservatives, the Liberal Democrats, the Greens and Nigel Faragersquos newly formed Brexit Party.But the MPs claimedthe party had had ldquoa clear commitment to fight to remain in the EU it could have won in the capital and areas like East Lothian.ldquoInstead, we were decimated, they said.ldquoIt is official Labour Party policy to support a Peoplersquos Vote as a way out of this catastrophic mess, yet Jeremy Corbyn snubbed our membership and refused to embrace it. As a result he personally handed victory to Nigel Farage.They also hit out at Scottish Labour, saying the party north of the border ldquocould have chosen very dferent path.They continued: ldquoThis was Jeremy Corbyn and Richard Leonardrsquos manesto, their message, their decision to ignore the membership and what voters were saying to us. It was their election campaign and their mess.ldquoThey stuck their heads in the Brexit sand because they canrsquot lead. We have paid the price for their failure and we have been wiped off the electoral map.The two MPs added: ldquoThese results must now act an urgent wake-up call for Richard Leonard, deputy leader Lesley Laird and campaigns manager Neil Findlay.ldquoIf there is to be any hope of recovery, Scottish Labour must become a passionate, relentless, and vocal voice for a final say on Brexit. There can be no ambiguity ndash any Brexit deal simply must be put to the public.ldquoWe must commit to remaining in the EU, and campaign for thisthere is a snap general election.ldquoScottish Labour can lead the wider Labour movement on this, and should have been doing so for many months.Mr Leonard said that he was ldquopersonally extremely sad Mr Martin had lost his seat.The Scottish Labour leader said: ldquoLabour was the only party fighting this election to bring the country back together.ldquoThe isions caused by the competing nationalisms of the UK and Scottish Governments continue to be a distraction from both of their failures.He insisted the party had put ldquoeverything into our campaign and were confident that our focus on jobs and a fair wage, schools and community would resonate with voters.And he said he would ldquocontinue to put all my efforts into rebuilding the party for the many, not the few.

title: nicola-sturgeon-eu-treats-ireland-better-than-westminster-treats-scotland
story: The First Minister criticised the UK Government for treating Scotland with "utter contempt" over Brexit.She spoke out during a trip to Dublin, where she met Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, business leaders and schoolchildren.Ms Sturgeon said: "We voted over % to remain, we have tried very hard in the wake of the UK-wide Brexit vote to find compromises and protect our interests, and we have worked hard across party lines to try to prevent the worst impact of Brexit, and we have been ignored."Votes in the Scottish Parliament have been cast aside, they have even in the process of the Brexit fiasco taken powers away from the Scottish Parliament in order to centralise how they deal with all of this."Scotland has been treated with contempt by Westminster and people are contrasting that with Ireland, that has been shown real solidarity and support from the European Union."Suddenly this idea of being a small independent country in the European Union, we only have to look at Ireland to see the benefits of that and many people are having their eyes opened."Scotland and Ireland share a long-standing history and it is vital that existing bonds are lsquostrengthened not strainedrsquo as the UK heads towards the EU exit, First Minister @NicolaSturgeon said today following her meeting with @LeoVaradkar ######### https:t.co fxWpLbUb pic ITnBeBMs Sturgeon spoke in a public conversation with Dearbhail McDonald at the Royal Irish Academy in Dublin during her visit on Monday.She said she expects Scotland will vote for independence the next time a referendum is held, adding the relationship between her nation and Ireland will grow even stronger then."There will be another Scottish independence referendum and I will make a prediction today that Scotland will vote for independence and we will become an independent country just like Ireland, and the strong relationship between our two countries now will become even stronger soon," she said."I want to see Scotland having the choice of independence within this term of the Scottish Parliament, which ends in May , so towards the latter half of next year would be when I think is the right time for that choice.":SNP European election result is endorsement of record in government - Nicola SturgeonMs Sturgeon also said the Scottish National Party have examined Irelands path to independence in their own planning."The proposition that my party is putting forward now is that we should follow the same path that Ireland followed when it became independent, we use the pound which is our currency until such times as the economic conditions are right to move to an independent Scottish currency, its a perfectly well-trodden path," she said.Later, Ms Sturgeon met Irish business leaders, schoolchildren and Taoiseach Leo Varadkar.She described the visit as having "highlighted the benefits of EU membership for Ireland and exactly what Scotland would miss out ontaken out of the EU against our will."Ireland is Scotlands closest international trading partner and our fth largest export market," she said."It is in the interest of both countries to ensure that we continue to work together and cooperate, not just on an economic level but also in dealing with similar challenges around political engagement."This is exactly why we must strengthen, not strain these bonds."

title: corbyn-subtly-shifts-brexit-position-saying-labour-prepared-to-support-public-vote-on-any-deal
story: The move came in the wake of the partyrsquos ldquodisastrous showing in the Euro-poll when Labour lost  of its  MEPs and managed only  per cent of the vote to place it third behind Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party and the Liberal Democrats.This was blamed on Labourrsquos so-called ldquoconstructive ambiguity approach an equivocal message aimed at keeping support among both Leave and Remain voters.Following the Euro-poll result, Mr Corbyn said he would consult MPs, shadow ministers, party members and affiliates with a view to ldquobring the issue back to conference in September.However, in a letter to MPs last night, he again explained Labourrsquos preference would be for a general election but also pointed out that any Brexit deal had to be ldquoput to a public vote.Labour sources said this was a clear sht from his previous position that a second poll was being kept only as an option on the table to stop a damaging Tory Brexit.ldquoIt is clear that the deadlock in Parliament can now only be broken by the issue going back to the people through a general election or a public vote. We are ready to support a public vote on any deal, declared Mr Corbyn.While his statement moves the party closer to backing a Peoplersquos Vote, it will not go far enough for some of his senior colleagues, who want their leader to back outright a second referendum being held without delay and for the party to campaign for Remain in it.In the aftermath of the vote, senior colleague after senior colleague lined up to urge the Labour leader to change direction on Brexit.Emily Thornberry, the Shadow Foreign Secretary, tore into her partys position live on air, saying: ldquoWe sent people out to campaign on that and, unfortunately, we just werent clear enough.She added: "I fear we will have no deal and we must be clear it will be a disaster for the country so we must have a second referendum."Tom Watson, the deputy leader, who has backed a second vote, said: ldquoFollowing the disastrous EU election results, Labour urgently needs to re-think its Brexit position and realign with members and voters."His frontbench colleague Sir Keir Starmer said the party needed to reflect hard and listen to Labour members, supporters and voters."The only way to break the Brexit impasse is to go back to the public with a choice between a credible Leave option and Remain," he insisted.The calls for a change of tack also came from Mr Corbynrsquos closest friends in the Shadow Cabinet.John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, hardened his position, tweeting: ldquoOf course, I want a general election. But I realise how dficult this is to secure. I will do anything I can to block no-deal Brexit. So yes , as likely GE not possible, then I support going back to the people in another referendum."Diane Abbott, the Shadow Home Secretary, also too to social media, saying: "We have to take the time to analyse the EU vote. But, when we come in third after the Brexit party, that is a clue something is wrong with our strategy. We need to listen to our members and take a clearer line on a public vote."But Len McCluskey, the leader of the Unite union and a close ally of Mr Corbyn, urged the party to ldquohold our nerve and not abandon the ldquohonourable objective of uniting the nation on Brexit.In what appeared a thinly-veiled dig at Mr Watson, the trade union chief warned some were now rushing to advance other agendas but were doing so to undermine the party leader."They will be seen for what they are and never forgiven by the members," he added.

title: leonard-faces-msps-wrath-after-labours-euro-wipe-out
story: The Scottish Labour leader also faces calls for an emergency meeting of the partyrsquos ruling body in Scotland which could potentially discuss his future.One party source said no one wanted another leadership contest, but the decline during Mr Leonardrsquos  months in charge was so bad every MP and MSP now feared for their job.Labour, which once dominated Scotland for generations was reduced to fth place in the European election, slumping from  to  per cent of the vote and losing both its MEPs, including David Martin, the UKrsquos longest-serving MEP, who was first elected in .:Tories and Labour panic as election sparks demand for Brexit and indyref votesIt was the partyrsquos worst result north of the border since .Even in the former Labour heartland of Glasgow, Labourrsquos vote fell from  to just %.Two Scottish Labour MPs issued an excoriating public criticism of Mr Leonard, his lieutenants, and the UK Leader Jeremy Corbyn for the partyrsquos disastrous performance.Edinburgh Southrsquos Ian Murray and East Lothianrsquos Martin Whitfield said voters had delivered an ldquoutterly damning verdict on Labourrsquos ambivalence on Brexit, and said of Mr Corbyn and Mr Leonard: ldquoThey stuck their heads in the Brexit sand because they canrsquot lead.Demanding Labour support a Peoplersquos Vote, they said: ldquoIf we fail to listen and learn, our party will never recover.ldquoThey criticised for Mr Leonard, a Corbyn loyalist, for ldquomeekly echoing the UK labour campaign, even putting Mr Corbynrsquos face on leaflets instead of the Scottish leader.They wrote: ldquoThe blame for the worst result in Scottish Labourrsquos history lies squarely with our partyrsquos leadership.ldquoIt is official Labour Party policy to support a Peoplersquos Vote as a way out of this catastrophic mess, yet Jeremy Corbyn snubbed our membership and refused to embrace it.ldquoAs a result, he personally handed victory to Nigel Farage.ldquoThis was Jeremy Corbyn and Richard Leonardrsquos manesto, their message, their decision to ignore the membership and what voters were saying to us.ldquoIt was their election campaign and their mess. They stuck their heads in the Brexit sand because they canrsquot lead.ldquoWe have paid the price for their failure and we have been wiped off the electoral map.ldquoThese results must now act an urgent wake-up call for Richard Leonard, deputy leader Lesley Laird and campaigns manager Neil Findlay.:Scottish Labour MPs slam leadership saying party may lsquonever recoverrsquo from lsquoworst everrsquo resultMr Martin, , said Labour had suffered because of a lack of a clear message on Brexit.He said: ldquoOur message was poor, we didnrsquot really communicate our position and some people might say that is because we donrsquot have one.ldquoIn fairness to Corbyn I think he genuinely thinks he has to deliver on the result of the national referendum, but on the other hand he has seen over the last few years how damaging Brexit is going to be to the country.ldquoHe is trying to ride two horses and it has, of course, proved impossible.He added: ldquoLabourrsquos message from the outset should have been we are the party which wants to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom and keep the UK in Europe, and reform both.Johanna Baxter, a member of Labourrsquos Scottish Executive Committee , said the result reflected a ldquofailure of leadership on the biggest issue to face the country in generations.In a letter to Mr Leonard, she said: ldquoThe SEC is not due to meet again until September.ldquoWe cannot wait until September to address the causes of this defeat. I request that an urgent meeting of the SEC is scheduled as soon as possible to discuss how this position is going to be resolved.Remarkably, Mr Leonard initially responded to the result by issuing a statement that didnrsquot mention Brexit.ldquoThe isions caused by the competing nationalisms of the UK and Scottish Governments continue to be a distraction from both of their failures, he said.ldquoLabour must, and will, do more to challenge these failures and put forward our positive alternatives to invest in our people, our communities and our public services.He later issued an email to party members admitted the public had lost trust in Labour, declaring he now backed ldquothe option to remain and that any Brexit deal should be ratied by a second public vote.However even this appeared to be parroting Mr Corbynrsquos position and relied on a ldquodeal that looks as far away as ever.Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson said: ldquoLabourrsquos result was catastrophic for a party that had near hegemony in Scotland in my letime. I donrsquot even know how they answer to that.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoLabour thought they were being smart by trying to bridge the ide when all they were doing was sitting on the fence. It was unclear exactly what they were standing for. I hope the Labour party learn that lesson and back a Peoplersquos Vote so we can put an end to this nonsense.David Clarke, Vice-Chair of the European Movement in Scotland, said: ldquoScottish Labour saw its vote virtually halve to just .%, its worst result ever ndash a direct consequence of its UK leadershiprsquos equivocation over the EU and, above all, a second referendum.ldquoWe therefore call upon UK Labour and the Scottish Labour Party to reverse their stance so far and to openly demand a Peoplersquos Vote, with the option of Remain on the ballot paper.

title: cab-drivers-face-tests-on-english-and-capability-behind-the-wheel
story: Members of Glasgow City Councilrsquos licensing committee are expected to introduce a policy, as suggested by Unite Glasgow Cab Section, which means taxis and private hire car drivers will need to complete an SQA qualication before they can take passengers.In February Konstantinos Theodoropoulos was denied a cab licence in February because he could not identy the City Chambers despite being inside the building opposite.Figures have also revealed the number of complaints made against cab companies in the city has more than doubled in five years.Between  and  the number of incidents rose from  to ,.The number of private hire car drivers has increased, while the councilrsquos licensing committee has dealt with complaints of pirating, cherry-picking hires and over-charging fares.Drivers have also refused to assist wheelchair users or carry guide dogs.A report submitted to the council reveals that the course would cost between pound and pound per driver.While it is hoped the level of customer service will be improved, concerns have been raised by some representatives that the time needed to complete the course could be ldquodetrimental and impact the number of people willing to enter the trade.Alex Wilson, chairman of the licensing board, said: ldquoWe are hoping the qualication will raise the standards of our drivers.ldquoIt is going to replace the existing customer care course which is really outdated.ldquoThe qualication will include a language test and suitable ways to help passengers with disabilities and mental health problems.ldquoThere is already a code of conduct in place for taxi drivers but this new policy will include private hires.ldquoIt will be mandatory for every new driver to complete.ldquoExisting drivers will have to complete it before they renew their licence.:What it feels like to hellip be a night sht Glasgow taxi driverldquoWe want drivers that know their way around Glasgow.ldquoApplicants will have to know where key locations are ndash including the City Chambers.The new SQA qualication will replace the existing customer care course which is considered no longer fit for purpose.A programme was created by the SQA in October last year to help taxi and private hire car drivers adapt to the challenges they face on a daily basis.This certicate in Introduction to the Role of the Professional Taxi and Private Hire Driver at SCQF level  has nine mandatory units.They are: workplace health and safety, safety transport passengers, professional customer service, maintain the safety of the licensed vehicle, mobility and wheelchair assistance, plan routes and fares, transport luggage and parcels, safely transport school age children and the licensing regulations Scotland.From January , , all applicants will require to have completed the training prior to submitting their application. Existing licence holders whose licence needs to be renewed from April , , will need to complete their training before renewing their licence.Warning that standards had been deteriorating, Calum Anderson, of the Glasgow Cab Section, said he was happy that the council had ldquoembraced the unionrsquos idea. He added: ldquoThe standards of private hire car drivers and taxi services are going down. It is ridiculous taxis and cab drivers can gain a licence without a qualication or any training.ldquoIf someone is required to do training, it means they will take time and effort to achieve their qualication.Mr Anderson added: ldquoI am hoping it will deter anyone from coming into the profession for just a casual exercise.ldquoWe want quality not quantity.It is hoped the course will be available by January.

title: nicola-sturgeon-plans-for-indyref2-next-year
story: On a visit to Dublin, the First Minister said her preference was for a vote in the latter half of , and legislation for another vote would be published at Holyrood on Wednesday.Opposition parties accused her of ldquodeceit and of misusing the SNPrsquos win in the European election, which she had insisted was about Brexit.Less than a fortnight ago, Ms Sturgeon said voting SNP was the strongest way to send a message that Scotland wanted to Remain ldquowhether you are for or against independence.The SNP recorded its best ever result in the European election, improving its share of the vote from . to . per cent, and picking up a third MEP to give it half of Scotlandrsquos representation in Brussels.Alyn Smith was re-elected and joined by former MSP Christian Allard and former minister Aileen McLeod, only the SNPrsquos second female MEP after Winnie Ewing.Ms Sturgeon said last month she would bring forward a ldquoframework bill in readiness for a second independence referendum in May, admitting it would need a transfer of power from Westminster to have legal effect.With Theresa May and her successor as prime minister unlikely to grant a Section  order, the referendum bill is essentially a campaign tool for the  Holyrood election.Ms Sturgeonrsquos timetable also indicates the bill is more theatrical than practical, as it implies an unrealistic six to nine-month transition to independence before the election.The First Minister, who met Taoiseach Leo Varadkar during her Irish trip, said the UK Government had treated Scotland with ldquoutter contempt through the Brexit process, while Ireland was respected.She said: ldquoSuddenly this idea of being a small independent country in the European Union, we only have to look at Ireland to see the benefits of that and many people are having their eyes opened.ldquoThere will be another Scottish independence referendum and I will make a prediction today that Scotland will vote for independence and we will become an independent country just like Ireland, and the strong relationship between our two countries now will become even stronger soon.ldquoI want to see Scotland having the choice of independence within this term of the Scottish Parliament, which ends in May , so towards the latter half of next year would be when I think is the right time for that choice.In a separate BBC interview, she added: ldquoThis week we will bring forward legislation to put in place the rules for giving people the choice in an independence referendum over a Brexit future or a future as an independent European nation.Speaking to the media at Edinburgh City Chambers, where the results for Scotland were confirmed after the Western Isles declared on Monday morning, Mr Smyth also said Scots wanted to stop Brexit andthat didnrsquot happen independence was ldquoback on the table.He said: ldquoWe reserve all our rights to do whatrsquos necessary for Scotlandrsquos best interests. So the independence question is back on the table, as it has been since the EU referendum.ldquoWe donrsquot want to see Scotland dragged out of the EU against our will.ldquoWe were told in  we were a partnership of nations, a partnership of equals, wersquore now being told to shut up and get to the back of the bus.ldquoThe people want better than that and they deserve better than that.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the election result had cemented the SNPrsquos case for another referendum in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Scottish Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoThe SNP went into this election pretending to voters that it was nothing to do with independence. Yet within hours of it being announced, Nicola Sturgeon is specically using it to argue for separation.ldquoThatrsquos fraudulent behaviour from an SNP Government thatrsquos meant to be running the country, not trying to break it up.
